column73:
Bills from the SFPUC are due and payable 15 days after the bill date. If customers have not paid by day 30, they are charged a late payment fee. On day 45, a reminder notice will be sent giving the customer 15 days to pay the amount due. If bills are not paid by day 60, the SFPUC will review the customer's account to then either be shutoff or go through the liens process. For accounts that go through the shut off process, a water discontinuation notice is mailed to the customer giving them 15 days to pay the delinquent balance, shut off occurs at day 75.  
As part of the COVID-19 response, the SFPUC suspended water and power shut offs due to late payments, postponed liens and collections, waived late fees, and provided rental payment deferments for tenants of our facilities through December 31st with possibility of extending through June 2021. 
The data provided in this survey is for accounts with balances over 30 days from bill date.

column48: Although the number of delinquent accounts has only increased by 343 accounts, our total dollar amount of delinquent accounts has grown considerably.  Pre-COVID delinquent dollar amount for water and sewer was $141,343.58 while POST-Covid (as of 10/31/20) is now $1,086,963.02 - an increase of almost $946,000.  If we are unable to collect on these past-due balances, any uncollected amounts will have to be offset by higher rates in the future.  This will adversely affect our paying customers, who come from all economic circumstances.
column72: Because we are not able to turn off services based on the Governor's Executive Order, we are not receiving as many payment arrangements requests as we have normally seen.  Prior to COVID, we averaged about 614 arrangements per month.  Currently, we are averaging about 172 arrangements per month.  Please also note the comment about increased delinquent balances in line 30 above.
column73: It is important to note that we have customers that are paying their bills, regardless of their employment status or possible economic hardships.  On the flip side, we also have customers that are choosing to not pay their bill based on the Governor's Executive Order, even if capable of paying their bills.   We are currently and have additional plans in place to work with customers to bring accounts current, including extended terms for bill repayment, the ability to accept EBT cards with cash aid benefits and a low income assistance program.  It should be noted that the longer the shutoff moratorium is extended, the larger the delinquent amounts will grow, which will only exacerbate re-payment impacts for customers (may become too unmanageable) or negative impacts to District revenues.
column74: The majority of our customer base lies within zip codes 92530  and 92532, which would explain the higher values in these rows.  As you would expect, the areas with higher income levels have less delinquent accounts as opposed to those with lower income levels.
column75: As part of assisting our customers negatively impacted by the COVID pandemic and in reaction to various Executive Orders by the Governor, the District  also deferred our rate increases scheduled to take effect July 1st, 2020 to now April 1, 2021, resulting in an estimated $2,993,000 loss of revenue.  This revenue loss is in addition to the delinquency amounts that continue to accrue as the shutoff moratorium continues. column73:
Rancho California Water District (RCWD) appreciates the opportunity to provide feedback regarding the COVID-19 financial impacts on water agencies.  It is extremely important that any customer accumulated debt, regardless of when it was accrued, is not allowed to be forgiven or discharged.  Agencies are not in a financial position to forgive debt as rates and fees are not set to account for this.  Additionally, forgiving any debt would be a clear violation of Proposition 218 and would require some of our ratepayers to subsidize others.  It would also set a poor precedent for any future financial challenges and hardships. 

Additionally, at the point when the shutoff order is lifted, it is imperative that debt accumulated before the order was lifted and debt accumulated after the order is lifted are treated separately and distinctly.  Customers would not be shutoff for debt accumulated before the shutoff order was lifted and districts would work with those customers to establish payment plans and other repayment opportunities.  However, any debt accumulated beginning on or after the date the order is lifted would be subject to each district’s billing and collections process up to and including disconnect for non-payment.  Agencies need to be able to operate under clear rules and understanding. This benefits both the agency and customers by having well defined procedures to reference. 

RCWD also provides water service to a large number of agricultural accounts.  These accounts would be considered smaller operations than those agricultural accounts typically found in the central valley, but they do make up a significant portion of RCWD’s water sales.  Because many of these operations are small in scale and/or family owned, we have not been disconnecting service for non-payment since the governor’s shutoff order.  The financial impact of these agricultural accounts to our agency is not represented in the survey numbers.  Therefore, it’s important to highlight these accounts in order to provide a wider view of the total impact that the emergency order has created for our district.  While the survey is focused on the residential impact, there are many more factors that feed into the financial health of an agency.
